message_1: Suppose two players are playing a centipede game, where Player 1 starts with a stack of 20 coins and both players take turns either taking 1 or 2 coins from the stack. The first player to take the coins wins. If Player 2 takes the coins before Player 1, Player 2 wins. What is the optimal strategy for Player 1 to ensure they win the game?
message_2:
The optimal strategy for Player 1 to ensure they win the game is to always take 1 coin on their turn. This forces Player 2 to take either 1 or 2 coins on their turn. By taking only 1 coin, Player 1 ensures that they will always have a turn when there is only 1 coin left in the stack, allowing them to take the last coin and win the game.

Here's a breakdown of the strategy:

1. Player 1 takes 1 coin (19 coins left).
2. Player 2 takes either 1 or 2 coins (17 or 18 coins left).
3. Player 1 takes 1 coin (16 or 17 coins left).
4. Player 2 takes either 1 or 2 coins (14, 15, 16 coins left).
5. Player 1 takes 1 coin (13, 14, or 15 coins left).

This pattern continues until there is only 1 coin left, at which point Player 1 takes the last coin and wins the game.
